Title.evidence: This study examined the efficacy and safety of the bupivacaine implant (300 mg) compared with placebo for postsurgical pain after abdominoplasty.

Trial_Design.evidence: In this double-blind, placebo-controlled study, patients undergoing abdominoplasty were randomized to three 100 mg bupivacaine implants or three placebo collagen implants, in a 1:1 ratio, implanted intraoperatively.

Intervention.evidence: patients undergoing abdominoplasty were randomized to three 100 mg bupivacaine implants or three placebo collagen implants

Objective.evidence: This study examined the efficacy and safety of the bupivacaine implant (300 mg) compared with placebo for postsurgical pain after abdominoplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcome: the analgesic effect of the bupivacaine implants through 24 hours postsurgery, measured by the sum of time-weighted pain intensity (SPI24).

Number_Randomised.evidence: The bupivacaine implant patients (n=181) reported statistically significant lower SPI24

Number_Analysed.evidence: The bupivacaine implant patients (n=181) reported statistically significant lower SPI24

Result_Outcome.evidence: The bupivacaine implant patients (n=181) reported statistically significant lower SPI24 (mean (SD) SPI24=102 (43), 95% CI 95 to 109) compared with placebo patients (n=184; SPI24=117 (45), 95% CI 111 to 123, p=0.002).

Harms.evidence: The only adverse event occurring in ≥5% of patients and for which proportion INL-001 >placebo was back pain (7.7% vs 7.6%).
